Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
@Mylo @Alright @TonyL @dukeleto @grewalsatinder @artemciy_dice @dimxy @lukechilds @Deleted User  
can we have a doc similar to this: https://docs.komodoplatform.com/komodo/python-rpc-komodod.html
for all the backend programming languages, starting from C, C++ to javascript,  RUST, Go and java ?
the slickrpc module used in the python doc above is just a wrapper around a regular curl command : https://github.com/barjomet/slick-bitcoinrpc/blob/master/slickrpc/rpc.py
it was developed with bitcoin in mind, but it can be used with komodo too

I expect similar things are already available in all the above languages for bitcoin so we need people who know these languages to look for the specific packages/modules/code-snippets and write a simple readme with instructions on how to call an rpc and how to receive its output in the above languages

This will be a valuable addition to our docs and reduce some barrier to newer devs that are experimenting and are not comfortable with bash scripting or just copy pasting comands into the terminal

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: @gcharang kmdgo has that already covered from code perspective. It also has go doc within its code. I can improve it's documentation within it's code for sure. Will be back to it soon.

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: thanks @grewalsatinder will check it out

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: Yes, have a look at the repo readme. Would like to know the places it can be improved. Thanks for asking on it mate. üôÇ

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
just remembered we have this list: https://docs.komodoplatform.com/resources/third-party-repos-resources.html#rpc-clients-and-wrappers
do suggest if I have left out any repos

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
it depends on security point of view.   we haven't in the past because these wrapper libs are not tested by security team, and endorsing them for use on komodo has been against the security ethos.   this is why they are not hosted on any komodo repos etc.

we can discuss in team meeting this week.  plz bring it up if i forget üòÉ

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: last week i took my javascript-rpc for web browser, and removed the `axios` dependency so it uses the browser native `fetch` commands, so there is no dependency.   it still requires a proxy between daemon and browser, but it's only for providing browser examples...

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢ i agree with you, and think there should be a z_listtransactions, but there isn't, ZEC mixed all that stuff into listtransactions

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @webworker01 I understand I can go "figure out the way to do what I need", but I am asking if the API is designed intuitively for people that should consume it, i.e. wallet developers, smart contract devs, etc...

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: If stuff from upstream makes no sense, we should change it

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Alright this is not critical, more of an "aesthetics of APIs". We have to constantly consume these APIs, and teach others to use them. I feel it's important to take pride in them and make them better versus the stance of "this is how it's always been done"

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the current design of the API makes GUI wallets for zaddrs inefficient

Author: Alright#0419
Content: what is it you need to do? Just a z_listtransactions kind of thing?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: in addition to it being un-intuitive and ugly to my eyes

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Alright i believe that myself and radix42 have wanted that in the past. Without it, you must iterate over every zaddr, and make an RPC call for all xtns of that zaddr via z_listreceivedbyaddress. If you have many zaddrs with no xtns, this is very wasteful. And GUI wallets perform this operation every 10 seconds

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it would benefit Pirate to have it as well, it would make GUI wallets take less resources

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, lets make new rpc calls!

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: just don't break the old shit

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I will be making z_createrawtransaction, z_signrawtransaction and z_sendrawtransaction to support raw zaddr xtns and minimize any risk of introducing bugs into their non-zaddr cousins

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: z_listtransactions is definitely an optimization for GUI wallets, which benefits Pirate/ac_private=1 chains the most

Author: jorian#4555
Content: i've been adding all RPCs to my Rust pet project, making a rpc client. there is a lot of weird irregularities between rpc calls

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I would love to have it for Hush, could probably do it myself, but would gladly let somebody else

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jorian are you talking about the lovely function signatures of different RPCs?

Author: jorian#4555
Content: ```just don't break the old shit``` is probably why it is like this

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and the fact that escaping rules cross 2 languages

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: you must appropriately escape JSON in your incoming language such that it is properly escaped when it hits the JSON RPC interface

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I can't describe how many subtle/crazy bugs are caused by that

Author: jorian#4555
Content: yes, among many other things, like using camelcasing in some calls, but snakecasing it in others

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: try using a non-ascii character in the password of your rpc

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: many libraries will fail to connect

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i could go on

Author: Alright#0419
Content: btw, don't think that's documented yet. `-testnode=1` allows you to run a network with a single node. Crazy convenient for testing
